With kind console, Affliction's frown to cheer;</br>To wipe from Poverty the falling tear;</br>On wounded Virtue pour the healing balm,</br>And lend to Misery Compassion's arm;</br>His be the task whom God ordains to preach,</br>The poor to comfort, and the rich to teach,</br>To cold Despair reviving hopes to give,</br>And bid the pale-ey'd virgin smile and live.</br>Such is the parish-priest:  his duty such,</br>Inur'd to scenes of woe and sickness much;</br>Long grown familiar with disease and pains</br>And such the priest of Arno's happy plain.

His form fond Memory will oft pourtray:</br>Hoary his head by many a winter's day;</br>His brow unfurrow'd by the touch of care;</br>His breast no refuge for the fiend Despair.</br>Content and calm in humble peace he stood,</br>Meek, learned, kind, benevolent, and good.</br>The soft humility, the tender heart,</br>Long us'd to take pale Pity's fostering part;</br>Friend to the friendless, still relieving woe:</br>So you may paint an angel here below.</br>To him belongs no consequential air;</br>No solemn farce of mockery and prayer;</br>No look that speaks disgust; no settled frown;</br>No pertness, ill mistaken for renown.</br>A mind to ev'ry virtue form'd to cleave;</br>Its wish, the throbs of anguish to relieve;</br>Its prayers for man; its hope in God consign'd;</br>Its practice, charity to all mankind.</br>To him no pomp of many a prelate proud;</br>No eloquence, theatrical and loud;</br>He calls not Rhetoric's fastidious train</br>To stagger, puzzle, and confuse the brain;</br>He comes in love and charity to preach;</br>He comes to learn humility, and teach.

Aye, there he lives, beneath yon thicket's side,</br>Where runs in haste the riv'let's babbling tide,</br>Where bending beeches overarch the glade,</br>And hide the cottage, a nest form'd in shade,</br>One wand'ring pathway shews the neat abode,</br>Thro' woods meand'ring to the upland road;</br>The casement crown'd with eglantine, between,</br>Just gains a view — the village and the green;</br>And there the white-thorn, scene of many a feat,</br>The walk, the slope, the arbour, and the seat;</br>No dome is his with gay luxurious show,</br>That far o'erlooks the modest spire below;</br>No grating hinges, slowly mov'd, declare</br>How much unwelcome is the trav'ller there;</br>No iron fence to keep the poor in awe,</br>His latch accustom'd, at the touch, to draw</br>Alike to all the hospitable door,</br>The blind, the maim'd, the friendless, and the poor;</br>No surly mastiff prowls around the gate,</br>Lets the rich enter, bids the poor to wait;</br>One only spaniel, courteous all to greet,</br>Precedes the stranger to the fond retreat,</br>Barks as he goes, and, fondling all the while,</br>Waits to conduct him from the village stile.</br>Such is the man for whom our God has chose</br>The care of virtue and the sick man's woes;</br>To whom the afflicted never weep in vain,</br>Unheard, unsought, neglected to remain.

Unclose the door:  On yon low tatter'd bed</br>I see the sick man lay his languid head;</br>I feel the fainting pulse, I hear the sigh,</br>I see the pallid cheek, the closing eye;</br>He has no tender tie of father, friend;</br>No children round the bed obsequious tend;</br>He has no hopes on earth, content to lie,</br>Alone, forsaken by the world, to die.</br>In the deep cell, where chilling damps invade,</br>And dews and cold the plaister'd dungeon shade,</br>He lies; around him breathe no awful choir,</br>No organ heals, nor turns the sacred fire;</br>Long trains of nuns (no sad procession) there</br>Breathe on the dying saint an holy pray'r;</br>No tinkling censor rolls its fragrance round;</br>No painted priests adore, and kiss the ground;</br>No fancied angels to his sight are giv'n,</br>To waft the soul in ecstacy to heav'n:</br>Cold and appall'd he waits his coming doom,</br>And sees but death and terror in the tomb.

The good man comes, in voice of Pity calls,</br>And gilds with hope the cell's remotest walls;</br>Tells the sick man the path of joy to tread,</br>Forget the living, but adore the dead;</br>Points to the future heav'n in the sky;</br>Bids the pale wretch on Faith and Hope rely;</br>Shows, where the wretched will have rest he'll go;</br>And tells the vanity of all below.</br>
